body:
It should be quite easy to implement it in here. We already have the barebone training code. Pretty much we need to implement generator and discriminator and allow multiple discriminators to be used in the training code and that would be all. 

Also, there are some things to consider. HiFiGAN is faster than MelGAN but not faster than the multiband version.  I cannot compare MOS values since they use different datasets. However, using the same discriminators as HiFiGAN, one can achieve better results with MultiBand-MelGAN. Basically, they use all the discriminators and the loss functions we have in combination with a different generator architecture.

> Thanks @george-roussos.
> Samples sound very good (just listened to single speaker ljspeech version). What's the difference between HifiGAN v1, v2 and v3?
> 
> @domcross would the be worth a try for our thorsten dataset?

They aim for shorter synthesis times by reducing the hidden dimensions 😀 I have only used V1. It is longer than MelGAN and shorter than PWGAN.


> It should be quite easy to implement it in here. We already have the barebone training code. Pretty much we need to implement generator and discriminator and allow multiple discriminators to be used in the training code and that would be all.
> 
> Also, there are some things to consider. HiFiGAN is faster than MelGAN but not faster than the multiband version. I cannot compare MOS values since they use different datasets. However, using the same discriminators as HiFiGAN, one can achieve better results with MultiBand-MelGAN. Basically, they use all the discriminators and the loss functions we have in combination with a different generator architecture.

That is so nice to hear! Thanks for the insight. I think the multiple disciminators did it. The one thing HiFiGAN was better at (at least for my dataset) was the lower frequencies when the speaker glottalised. It is the only vocoder so far that was able to model it naturally. I had problems otherwise with every GAN and WaveGrad, even. Also, I agree with you about MultiBand MelGAN. If you think that a combination may work better, it is worth to try. Also, what do you think about PWGAN generator (since it is WaveNet inspired) and the multiple discriminators?

The way that I did training was what suggested on paper. First I trained on raw spectrograms for 1M steps and then finetuned using GTA extracted using my TTS.

> The way that I did training was what suggested on paper. First I trained on raw spectrograms for 1M steps and then finetuned using GTA extracted using my TTS.

That also was another difference for HifiGAN. Have you ever trained MelGAN with the same approach?

> > The way that I did training was what suggested on paper. First I trained on raw spectrograms for 1M steps and then finetuned using GTA extracted using my TTS.
> 
> That also was another difference for HifiGAN. Have you ever trained MelGAN with the same approach?

No sorry, so I don't know what results I could have gotten - however, with HiFiGAN (v1) performance on validation set (before finetuning on TTS spectrograms) was much better than MelGAN val or PWGAN val. It was so good that the only noticeable artifact was in sibilants. So I think HiFiGAN would have beat them.

The only thing that I tried was train PWGAN with TTS spectrograms from scratch. It was horrible.

> However, using the same discriminators as HiFiGAN, one can achieve better results with MultiBand-MelGAN. Basically, they use all the discriminators and the loss functions we have in combination with a different generator architecture.

Do you mean by keeping MBMelGAN's gen net unchanged, bug use HiFiGAN's dis nets(MPD, MSD), and use mel spec loss instead of stft loss as https://github.com/jik876/hifi-gan/blob/master/train.py?

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions. You might also look our discourse page for further help. https://discourse.mozilla.org/c/tts

I'd like to keep this issue open, because of the good compromise between quality and rtf (real time factor). Not sure if the implementation of @george-roussos, @Edresson and @SanjaESC could be easily transfered in tts repo code.

Hello, 
I am trying the hi-hi gan  from this repo:
https://github.com/george-roussos/hifi-gan

How to generate the files for the text to mel part? 
Thanks you
